required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Strength Training on Musculoskeletal Overuse Injuries in Female Runners
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Strength Training on Musculoskeletal Overuse Injuries in Female Runners

collaborator.agency: U.S. Army Medical Research and Materiel Command

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to look at the effect of strength training in preventing overuse injuries in female runners

detailed_description.textblock: This randomized clinical trial will compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on: (1) injury rates in female runners during the 9 month intervention period, and for 9 months after completing the intervention, and (2) on the potential mechanisms of injury including strength, joint and tissue loading, and psychosocial factors.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of Overuse Injury (Physical Exam/Injury Report Form)
primary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of a 9-month strength training program to a control group on the incidence of overuse, lower extremity, running injuries in female adult recreational and competitive runners during and 9 months subsequent to the training period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Lower Extremity Muscular Strength (HUMAC norm isokinetic dynamometer)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on lower extremity muscular strength at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Biomechanical Joint Moments (3D kinematic and kinetic data collected by 6-camera motion capture gait analysis)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on hip, knee, and ankle joint moments during running at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Biomechanical Joint Forces (3D kinematic and kinetic data collected by 6-camera motion capture gait analysis)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on knee and ankle compressive and shear bone-on-bone joint forces during running at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Biomechanical Joint Tissue Loading (3D kinematic and kinetic data collected by 6-camera motion capture gait analysis)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on joint tissue loading during running at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention.
To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on performance self-efficacy at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life (SF-12 Health Related Quality of Life Survey)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on health-related quality of life at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life (Satisfaction with Life Scale)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on health-related quality of life at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life (Positive and Negative Affect Scale)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on health-related quality of life at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life (State Trait Anxiety Inventory-S Scale)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on health-related quality of life at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of Life (Visual Analog Pain Scale)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the effects of 9-months of strength training to a control group on health-related quality of life at the conclusion and 9 months subsequent to completion of the intervention

arm_group.description: This group will begin coming to the Clinical Research Center (near the undergraduate campus of Wake Forest University) for exercise classes 3 days per week for about an hour each day. The class will consist of a 10-minute warm-up, a 20-minute strength training period, 15-minutes of neuromuscular (balance/coordination) training, and a 15-minute cool down. These regular exercise classes at Wake Forest will go on for 9 months, followed by another 9 months of follow-up via email and 2 group meetings at Fleet Feet (at months 12 and 15).

This group will be observed as they follow their usual run-training routine over the course of 18 months. Emails will be sent biweekly for 18 months to update the research team on injury/training status. The group will attend 5 group meetings at Fleet Feet (at months 1, 3, 6, 12, and 15). After the 18 months, they will be offered a free 6-week strength training program at the Clinical Research Center.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female civilian runners between 18-60 years old
- Run at least 5 miles per week for the past 6 months
- No overuse injuries in the past 6 months
- Plan to stay in the area for the next year and a half
- Live less than 30 miles from Wake Forest University
Exclusion Criteria:
- Male
- Under age 18 and over age 60
- Chronic diseases, orthopedic conditions, past anterior cruciate ligament tears
- Currently pregnant or planning to conceive within the next 18 months
- Observed by study staff as unwilling to attend testing/intervention sessions
- Observed by study staff as unwilling to communicate via telephone and email regularly with study personnel
- Participated in formal strength training in the past 6 months
- Current active military or active military reserve
